question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Let $\mathbb{I}$ be the set of irrational numbers. That is
$\mathbb{I}=\mathbb{R}-\mathbb{Q}$.

Prove the following statements:

(i) Let $x\in\mathbb{R}$. If $x\in\mathbb{I}$ then
$\frac{1}{x}\in\mathbb{I}$.

(ii) Let $n\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $x\in\mathbb{R}$. If $x\in\mathbb{I}$ then
$n+x\in\mathbb{I}$.
